Sharper Convergence Guarantees for Asynchronous SGD for Distributed and Federated Learning

Anastasia Koloskova
EPFL
anastasia.koloskova@epfl.ch
&Sebastian U. Stich
CISPA
stich@cispa.de
&Martin Jaggi
EPFL
martin.jaggi@epfl.ch
Abstract

We study the asynchronous stochastic gradient descent algorithm for distributed training over n𝑛n workers which have varying computation and communication frequency over time. In this algorithm, workers compute stochastic gradients in parallel at their own pace and return those to the server without any synchronization. Existing convergence rates of this algorithm for non-convex smooth objectives depend on the maximum gradient delay τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max} and show that an ε𝜀\varepsilon-stationary point is reached after 𝒪​(σ2​ε−2+τmax​ε−1)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏superscript𝜀1\mathcal{O}\!\left(\sigma^{2}\varepsilon^{-2}+\tau_{\max}\varepsilon^{-1}\right) iterations, where σ𝜎\sigma denotes the variance of stochastic gradients.
In this work (i) we obtain a tighter convergence rate of 𝒪​(σ2​ε−2+τmax​τa​v​g​ε−1)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔superscript𝜀1\mathcal{O}\!\left(\sigma^{2}\varepsilon^{-2}+\sqrt{\tau_{\max}\tau_{avg}}\varepsilon^{-1}\right) without any change in the algorithm where τa​v​gsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔\tau_{avg} is the average delay, which can be significantly smaller than τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max}. We also provide (ii) a simple delay-adaptive learning rate scheme, under which asynchronous SGD achieves a convergence rate of 𝒪​(σ2​ε−2+τa​v​g​ε−1)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔superscript𝜀1\mathcal{O}\!\left(\sigma^{2}\varepsilon^{-2}+\tau_{avg}\varepsilon^{-1}\right), and does not require any extra hyperparameter tuning nor extra communications. Our result allows to show for the first time that asynchronous SGD is always faster than mini-batch SGD. In addition, (iii) we consider the case of heterogeneous functions motivated by federated learning applications and improve the convergence rate by proving a weaker dependence on the maximum delay compared to prior works. In particular, we show that the heterogeneity term in convergence rate is only affected by the average delay within each worker.

1 Introduction

The stochastic gradient descent (SGD) algorithm [42, 12] and its variants (momentum SGD, Adam, etc.) form the foundation of modern machine learning and frequently achieve state of the art results. With recent growth in the size of models and available training data, parallel and distributed versions of SGD are becoming increasingly important [55, 16, 15]. Without those, modern state-of-the art language models [43], generative models [39, 40], and many others [49] would not be possible. In the distributed setting, also known as data-parallel training, optimization is distributed over many compute devices working in parallel (e.g. cores, or GPUs on a cluster) in order to speed up training. Every worker computes gradients on a subset of the training data, and the resulting gradients are aggregated (averaged) on a server.

The same type of SGD variants also form the core algorithms for federated learning applications [33, 23] where the training process is naturally distributed over the user devices, or clients, that keep their local data private, and only transfer the (e.g. encrypted or differentially private) gradients to the server.

A rich literature exists on the convergence theory of above mentioned parallel SGD methods, see e.g. [16, 12] and references therein. Plain parallel SGD still faces many challenges in practice, motivating research on various approaches to improve efficiency of distributed learning and mini-batch SGD. This includes for example communication compression techniques [2, 3, 47, 48], decentralized communication [28, 6, 35, 25] or performing several local SGD steps on workers before communicating with the server [29, 31, 33, 46].

These approaches use synchronous communication, where workers in each round are required to wait for the slowest one, before being able to start the next round of computations. In the presence of such straggler nodes or nodes that have different computation speeds, other workers face significant idle times. Asynchronous variants of SGD are aimed to solve such inefficiencies and use available workers more effectively. In asynchronous SGD, each worker starts the next computation immediately after finishing computing its own gradient, without waiting for any other workers. This is especially important in the presence of straggler nodes. Asynchronous algorithms were studied both in distributed and federated learning settings [41, 30, 26, 45, 36]. In this paper we focus on such challenging asynchronous variants of SGD and provide an improved theoretical analysis of convergence compared to prior works.

Most existing work has studied the convergence behavior of asynchronous SGD for the setting of homogeneous distributed training data, where worker’s objectives are i.i.d. . This assumption however is only realistic e.g. in shared-memory implementations where all processes can access the same data [41]. Under this assumption, it can be proven that asynchronous SGD finds an ε𝜀\varepsilon-approximate stationary point (squared gradient norm bounded by ε𝜀\varepsilon) in 𝒪​(σ2ε2+τmaxε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝜀\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\tau_{\max}}{\varepsilon}\big{)} iterations [47], for smooth non-convex functions. This complexity bound depends on the maximum delay of the gradients τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max} and the gradient variance σ>0𝜎0\sigma>0. Unfortunately, the maximal delay is a very pessimistic metric, not well reflecting the true behavior in practice. For instance, if a worker struggles just once, the maximum delay is large, while we would still expect reasonable overall convergence.

Two recent works [14, 8] tackle this issue by proposing two new delay-adaptive algorithms that achieve a convergence rate that depends only on the average delay of the applied gradients, with Aviv et al. [8] considering only the convex optimization and Cohen et al. [14] providing a rate of 𝒪​(σ2ε2+τa​v​gε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔𝜀\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\tau_{avg}}{\varepsilon}\big{)} for smooth non-convex functions. The average delay can be much smaller than the maximal delay, and thus these methods are robust to rare stragglers. However, Cohen et al. [14] requires twice more communications at every step, and an extra hyperparameter to tune. Aviv et al. [8] analyze only convex functions and assume a bound on the variance of the delays, which can frequently degrade with the maximum delay τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max}. Moreover, those works require the assumption that gradients are uniformly bounded.

In the realistic case of heterogeneous objective functions, that is in particular relevant in federated learning applications [23], all the existent convergence rates of asynchronous SGD depend on the maximum delay [36].

Contributions.

  • •

    For standard asynchronous SGD with constant stepsize, and with non-convex L𝐿L-smooth homogeneous objective functions, we prove the tighter convergence rate of 𝒪​(σ2ε2+τa​v​g​τmaxε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔subscript𝜏𝜀\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\sqrt{\tau_{avg}\tau_{\max}}}{\varepsilon}\big{)} to ε𝜀\varepsilon-small error. Under the additional assumption of bounded gradients, we obtain a convergence rate of 𝒪​(σ2ε2+τa​v​g​Gε3/2+τa​v​gε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔𝐺superscript𝜀32subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔𝜀\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\tau_{avg}G}{\varepsilon^{3/2}}+\frac{\tau_{avg}}{\varepsilon}\big{)} where G𝐺G is the bound on the norm of gradients. The previously best known rate was 𝒪​(σ2ε2+τmaxε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝜀\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\tau_{\max}}{\varepsilon}\big{)}.

  • •

    With homogeneous objective functions, we provide a delay-adaptive stepsize scheme that does not require tuning of any extra hyperparameters, and converges at the rate of 𝒪​(σ2ε2+τa​v​gε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔𝜀\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\tau_{avg}}{\varepsilon}\big{)} for non-convex L𝐿L-smooth functions.

  • •

    This result allows us to show that asynchronous SGD is always better than mini-batch SGD regardless of the delays pattern (under assumption that the server can perform operations with zero time).

  • •

    We also consider distributed optimization with heterogeneous objectives where the delays can depend on the nodes and give the convergence rate of 𝒪​(σ2ε2+ζ2ε2+τa​v​g​1n​∑i=1nζi2​τa​v​giε32+τa​v​g​τmaxε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2superscript𝜁2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑖2subscriptsuperscript𝜏𝑖𝑎𝑣𝑔superscript𝜀32subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔subscript𝜏𝜀\mathcal{O}\!\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\zeta^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\sqrt{\tau_{avg}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\zeta_{i}^{2}\tau^{i}_{avg}}}{\varepsilon^{\frac{3}{2}}}+\frac{\sqrt{\tau_{avg}\tau_{\max}}}{\varepsilon}\big{)}, where ζisubscript𝜁𝑖\zeta_{i}’s measure functions heterogeneity and τ¯isubscript¯𝜏𝑖\bar{\tau}_{i} is the average delay of node i𝑖i. This rate improves over the best previously-known results that had worse dependence on the maximum delay τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max}.

2 Related Work

Asynchronous SGD.

The research field of asynchronous optimization can be traced back at least to 1989 [10]. Recent works are heavily focused on its SGD variants, such as Hogwild! SGD [38] which deals with coordinate-wise asynchronity. Nguyen et al. [37] provided a tighter convergence analysis by removing the bounded gradient assumption. Our work does not focus on such a coordinate-wise asynchrony as it relies on sparsity assumption that is not realistic in modern machine learning applications. Mania et al. [30] introduces the perturbed iterate framework which enabled theoretical advances with tighter convergence rates [47, 45]. Leblond et al. [26] focus on asynchronous variance-reduced methods.

Many works [1, 13, 19, 5, 44, 27, 47, 17] focused on asynchronous SGD variants where workers communicate with the server without any synchronization, but these communications are considered to be atomic. All of these works provide convergence guarantees that depend on the maximum delay τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max} with [5, 47] providing the first tight convergence rates under assumption that the delays are always constant for quadratic and general (convex, strongly convex and non-convex) functions correspondingly. Stich et al. [45] showed a connection of large batches and delays, although still depending only on the maximum delay. Even et al. [18] consider a continuized view of the time (rather than classical per-iteration time) for asynchronous algorithms on a decentralized network.

Delay-adaptive methods.

The works [54, 53, 44, 50, 32, 17] considered delay-adaptive schemes to mitigate adversarial effect of stragglers, however with convergence rates that still depend on the maximum delay τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max}. Only Cohen et al. [14] in the non-convex, and Aviv et al. [8] in the convex case were able to obtain convergence rates depending on the average delay τa​v​gsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔\tau_{avg}. Concurrent to our work, Mishchenko et al. [34] provide a delay-adaptive scheme similar to ours and derive convergence guarantees depending on the concurrency τCsubscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{C}. However, they did not consider asynchronous SGD with constant stepsizes, nor the bounded gradients case. Moreover, for heterogeneous functions their method with delay adaptive stepsizes does not converge and only reaches an approximate solution (up to heterogeniety), while in our work we prove convergence for a different method with carefully tuned constant stepsizes.

Asynchronous federated learning.

In typical federated learning (FL) applications [33], clients or workers frequently have very different computing powers/speed. This makes especially appealing for practitioners to use asynchronous algorithms for FL [46, 36, 7, 52, 22, 9, 21, 51] with many of these works focusing on correcting for unequal participation ratio of different clients [51, 21, 22, 9, 52] by implementing variance reduction techniques on the server. Nguyen et al. [36] introduce the FedBuff algorithm that is very close to the algorithm that we consider in this work and show its practical superiority over classical synchronous FL algorithms.

4 Homogeneous Distributed Setting

We start with an important special case of problem (1) where the objective functions are identical for all workers, i.e. fi​(𝐱)≡fj​(𝐱)subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱subscript𝑓𝑗𝐱f_{i}(\mathbf{x})\equiv f_{j}(\mathbf{x}) for all i,j∈[n]𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑛i,j\in[n], such as in the case of homogeneously (i.i.d.) distributed training data. Consequently, this implies that Assumption 2 holds with ζi=0subscript𝜁𝑖0\zeta_{i}=0, i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]. Many classical works have focused on asynchronous algorithms under this homogeneous setting (e.g. [5, 47, 1, 19, 44, 27], see the related work for more references). This setting commonly appears in the datacenter setup for distributed training [15], where all nodes (or GPUs) have access to the full dataset or data distribution. Moreover, this special case allows us to present our main ideas in a simplified way, without complicating the presentation due to heterogeneity. We will later see that most of the results in this section can also be obtained as a corollary of the more general heterogeneous functions case (Section 5) by setting ζi=0​i∈[n]subscript𝜁𝑖0𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\zeta_{i}=0~{}i\in[n].

4.1 Algorithm

We consider standard asynchronous SGD (also known as delayed SGD, or SGD with stale updates) as presented in Algorithm 1, see e.g. [5, 47, 1, 19, 44, 27].

First, the server initializes training by selecting an initial active worker set 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0} and assigning 𝐱(0)superscript𝐱0\mathbf{x}^{(0)} to these workers. Throughout the algorithm, the active workers compute gradients at their own speed, based on their local data. On line 4, once some worker (which we denote as jtsubscript𝑗𝑡j_{t}) finishes computing its gradient, it sends the result to the server. On line 5 the server incorporates the received—possibly delayed—gradient, using a stepsize ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} that can depend on the gradient delay τtsubscript𝜏𝑡\tau_{t}. The gradient delay τtsubscript𝜏𝑡\tau_{t} is defined as the difference between the iteration at which worker jtsubscript𝑗𝑡j_{t} started to compute the gradient and the iteration t𝑡t at which it got applied. We index the stochastic noise of the gradients ξtsubscript𝜉𝑡\xi_{t} by iteration t𝑡t to highlight that previous iterates 𝐱(t′)superscript𝐱superscript𝑡′\mathbf{x}^{(t^{\prime})} for t′≤tsuperscript𝑡′𝑡t^{\prime}\leq t do not depend on this stochastic noise. However, the client selects the data sample ξtsubscript𝜉𝑡\xi_{t} at iteration t−τt𝑡subscript𝜏𝑡t-\tau_{t} when the computation starts. After that, on lines 6-7 the server selects the new active workers out of the ones that are currently inactive (including worker jtsubscript𝑗𝑡j_{t}) and assigns them the latest iterate 𝐱(t+1)superscript𝐱𝑡1\mathbf{x}^{(t+1)}.

In contrast to previous works, we explicitly define the set of workers that are busy with computations at every step t𝑡t as 𝒞tsubscript𝒞𝑡\mathcal{C}_{t} (the active workers set). Note that this does not pose any restrictions. A main advantage of allowing the sets 𝒞tsubscript𝒞𝑡\mathcal{C}_{t} to be different at every step t𝑡t lies in the possibility to also cover mini-batch SGD as a special case, which we discuss in Example 2. Our theoretical results depend on the size of these sets 𝒞tsubscript𝒞𝑡\mathcal{C}_{t}, a.k.a. the concurrency.

Definition 1 (Concurrency).

The concurrency τC(t)superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑡\tau_{C}^{(t)} at step t𝑡t is defined as the size of the active worker set 𝒞tsubscript𝒞𝑡\mathcal{C}_{t}, i.e. τC(t)=|𝒞t|superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑡subscript𝒞𝑡\tau_{C}^{(t)}=|\mathcal{C}_{t}|. We also define the maximum and average concurrency as

τC=maxt⁡{τC(t)},subscript𝜏𝐶subscript𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑡\displaystyle\tau_{C}=\max_{t}\{\tau_{C}^{(t)}\}\,, τ¯C=1T+1​∑t=0TτC(t).subscript¯𝜏𝐶1𝑇1superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑡\displaystyle\bar{\tau}_{C}=\textstyle\frac{1}{T+1}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\tau_{C}^{(t)}\,.

Note that in many practical scenarios, we have a constant concurrency of n𝑛n over time, meaning that all n𝑛n workers are active at every step, and thus τC=τ¯C=nsubscript𝜏𝐶subscript¯𝜏𝐶𝑛\tau_{C}=\bar{\tau}_{C}=n.

We discuss two important practical examples that fit into our Algorithm 1:

Example 2 (Mini-batch SGD).

Mini-batch SGD with batch size n𝑛n can be seen as a special case of Algorithm 1, as follows: The server (i) in line 1 selects all n𝑛n workers, 𝒞0=[n]subscript𝒞0delimited-[]𝑛\mathcal{C}_{0}=[n]; (ii) in line 6 does not select new workers while the gradients from the same batch have not been fully applied yet, i.e. 𝒜t=∅subscript𝒜𝑡\mathcal{A}_{t}=\emptyset if tmodn≠0modulo𝑡𝑛0t\!\!\mod n\neq 0; (iii) in line 6 selects 𝒜t=[n]subscript𝒜𝑡delimited-[]𝑛\mathcal{A}_{t}=[n] if tmodn=0modulo𝑡𝑛0t\!\!\mod n=0 to start a new batch.

Example 3 (Asynchronous SGD with maximum concurrency).

In practical implementations one should always aim to utilize all resources available and thus (i) in line 1 select all available workers 𝒞0=0subscript𝒞00\mathcal{C}_{0}=0; (ii) in line 6 select the worker that finished its computations 𝒜t={jt}subscript𝒜𝑡subscript𝑗𝑡\mathcal{A}_{t}=\{j_{t}\} so that workers are always busy with jobs.

4.2 Theoretical analysis: Constant stepsizes

We first formally define the average and maximum delays.

Definition 4 (Average and maximum delays).

Let {τt}t=0T−1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜏𝑡𝑡0𝑇1\{\tau_{t}\}_{t=0}^{T-1} be the delays of the applied gradients in Algorithm 1. We define {τi𝒞T}i∈𝒞T\{jT}subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝒞𝑇𝑖\subscript𝒞𝑇subscript𝑗𝑇\{\tau_{i}^{\mathcal{C}_{T}}\}_{i\in\mathcal{C}_{T}\backslash\{j_{T}\}} as the delays of gradients which are in flight at time T𝑇T, that is they have remained unapplied at the last step. Each τi𝒞Tsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝒞𝑇\tau_{i}^{\mathcal{C}_{T}} is equal to the difference between the last iteration T𝑇T and the iteration at which worker i𝑖i started to compute its last gradient. We then define the average and the maximum delays as τa​v​g=1T+|𝒞T|−1​(∑t=0T−1τt+∑i∈𝒞T\{jT}τi𝒞T),subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔1𝑇subscript𝒞𝑇1superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1subscript𝜏𝑡subscript𝑖\subscript𝒞𝑇subscript𝑗𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝒞𝑇\displaystyle\tau_{avg}=\frac{1}{T+|\mathcal{C}_{T}|-1}\bigg{(}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\tau_{t}+\sum_{i\in\mathcal{C}_{T}\backslash\{j_{T}\}}\tau_{i}^{\mathcal{C}_{T}}\bigg{)}, τmax=max⁡{maxt=1,…​T−1⁡τt,maxi∈𝒞T\{jT}⁡τi𝒞T}.subscript𝜏subscript𝑡1…𝑇1subscript𝜏𝑡subscript𝑖\subscript𝒞𝑇subscript𝑗𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝒞𝑇\displaystyle\tau_{\max}=\max\left\{\max_{t=1,\dots T-1}\tau_{t},\max_{i\in\mathcal{C}_{T}\backslash\{j_{T}\}}\tau_{i}^{\mathcal{C}_{T}}\right\}. (6)

We further provide a key observation on the connection between the average delay and the average concurrency. This observation, is one of the essential elements for achieving an improved analysis.

Remark 5 (Key Observation).

In Algorithm 1 the average concurrency τ¯Csubscript¯𝜏𝐶\bar{\tau}_{C} is connected to the average delay τa​v​gsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔\tau_{avg} as

τa​v​g=T+1T+|CT|−1​τ¯C=T>|CT|𝒪​(τ¯C).subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑇1𝑇subscript𝐶𝑇1subscript¯𝜏𝐶superscript𝑇subscript𝐶𝑇𝒪subscript¯𝜏𝐶\displaystyle\tau_{avg}=\frac{T+1}{T+|C_{T}|-1}\bar{\tau}_{C}~{}~{}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle T>|C_{T}|}}{{=}}~{}~{}\mathcal{O}\!\left(\bar{\tau}_{C}\right)\,. (7)

We explain this observation on a simple example. Assume that the concurrency is constant at every step (τC=τ¯Csubscript𝜏𝐶subscript¯𝜏𝐶\tau_{C}=\bar{\tau}_{C}), and that all workers except one are responding very rarely. Then on steps 4–5 of Algorithm 1 only this one responding worker would mostly participate. This means that for this one worker the delay τtsubscript𝜏𝑡\tau_{t} would be frequently equal to zero, and the overall average delay will be small.

Next, we provide our theoretical results. We first focus on the Asynchronous SGD Algorithm 1 under constant stepsizes, i.e. ηt≡ηsubscript𝜂𝑡𝜂\eta_{t}\equiv\eta. This setting was studied in many works such as [1, 19, 5, 27, 47]

Theorem 6 (Constant stepsizes).

Under Assumptions 1, 3, there exists a constant stepsize ηt≡ηsubscript𝜂𝑡𝜂\eta_{t}\equiv\eta such that for Algorithm 1 it holds that 1T+1​∑t=0T∥∇f​(𝐱(t))∥22≤ε1𝑇1superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝐱𝑡22𝜀\frac{1}{T+1}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(t)})\right\rVert_{2}^{2}\leq\varepsilon after

𝒪​(σ2ε2+τC​τmaxε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝐶subscript𝜏𝜀\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\!\left(\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\sqrt{\tau_{C}\tau_{\max}}}{\varepsilon}\right) iterations.iterations\displaystyle\text{iterations}. (8)

If we additionally assume bounded gradient Assumption 4, then 1∑t=0T|𝒜t|​∑t=0T|𝒜t|​∥∇f​(𝐱(t))∥22≤ε1superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇subscript𝒜𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇subscript𝒜𝑡superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝐱𝑡22𝜀\frac{1}{\sum_{t=0}^{T}|\mathcal{A}_{t}|}\sum_{t=0}^{T}|\mathcal{A}_{t}|\left\lVert\nabla f({\mathbf{x}}^{(t)})\right\rVert_{2}^{2}\leq\varepsilon after

𝒪​(σ2ε2+τC​Gε3/2+τCε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝐶𝐺superscript𝜀32subscript𝜏𝐶𝜀\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\!\left(\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\tau_{C}G}{\varepsilon^{3/2}}+\frac{\tau_{C}}{\varepsilon}\right) iterations. (9)

Under constant concurrency, we can directly connect τCsubscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{C} to the average delay τa​v​gsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔\tau_{avg} due to Remark 5. We highlight again that in practice, to get the best utilization of the available resources, practical implementations choose the maximum concurrency possible, which is equal to n𝑛n.

Corollary 7.

If in Algorithm 1 the concurrency is constant at every step (thus τC=τ¯Csubscript𝜏𝐶subscript¯𝜏𝐶\tau_{C}=\bar{\tau}_{C}), then under the same conditions as in Theorem 6 the convergence rate of Algorithm 1 is

𝒪​(σ2ε2+τa​v​g​τmaxε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔subscript𝜏𝜀\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\!\left(\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\sqrt{\tau_{avg}\tau_{\max}}}{\varepsilon}\right) and 𝒪​(σ2ε2+τa​v​g​Gε3/2+τa​v​gε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔𝐺superscript𝜀32subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔𝜀\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\!\left(\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\tau_{avg}G}{\varepsilon^{3/2}}+\frac{\tau_{avg}}{\varepsilon}\right) (10)

for the case without and with bounded gradient Assumption 4 correspondingly.

The previously best known convergence rate for Asynchronous SGD 1 under constant stepsizes was given in [47] and is equal to 𝒪​(σ2ε2+τmaxε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝜀\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\tau_{\max}}{\varepsilon}\big{)}. In our theorem we improved the delay dependence from τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max} to τa​v​g​τmaxsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔subscript𝜏\sqrt{\tau_{avg}\tau_{\max}} in the last term without any change in the algorithm, only by taking into account concurrency that is usually fixed in practical implementations anyways. No other work previously made an assumption on the number of computing workers in their theoretical analysis. τa​v​g​τmaxsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔subscript𝜏\sqrt{\tau_{avg}\tau_{\max}} could be much smaller than τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max} in the presence of rare straggler devices. With an additional assumption of bounded gradients, the dependence on the maximum delay can be completely removed.

4.3 Theoretical analysis: Delay-adaptive stepsizes

In many cases, the bounded gradient Assumption 4 is unrealistic [37], meaning that the gradient bound G𝐺G is often large and thus the rate (9) is loose. In this section we show that by weighting the stepsize down for the gradients that have a large delay, once can remove the dependence on the maximum delay τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max} without assuming bounded gradients (Assump. 4).

Theorem 8 (Delay-adaptive stepsizes).

There exist a parameter η≤14​L𝜂14𝐿\eta\leq\frac{1}{4L} such that if we set the stepsizes in Algorithm 1 dependent on the delays as

ηt={ητt≤τC,<min⁡{η,14​L​τt}τt>τC,subscript𝜂𝑡cases𝜂subscript𝜏𝑡subscript𝜏𝐶absent𝜂14𝐿subscript𝜏𝑡subscript𝜏𝑡subscript𝜏𝐶\displaystyle\eta_{t}=\begin{cases}\eta&\tau_{t}\leq\tau_{C},\\ <\min\{\eta,\frac{1}{4L\tau_{t}}\}\vspace{-1mm}&\tau_{t}>\tau_{C},\end{cases} (11)

then for Algorithm 1, under Assumptions 1, 3 it holds that 1∑t=0Tηt​∑t=0Tηt​∥∇f​(𝐱(t))∥22≤ε1superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇subscript𝜂𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇subscript𝜂𝑡superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝐱𝑡22𝜀\frac{1}{\sum_{t=0}^{T}\eta_{t}}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\eta_{t}\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(t)})\right\rVert_{2}^{2}\leq\varepsilon after

𝒪​(σ2ε2+τCε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝐶𝜀\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\!\left(\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{{\tau_{C}}}{\varepsilon}\right) iterations. (12)

In our theorem, the stepsize ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} in the case of large delays τt>τCsubscript𝜏𝑡subscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{t}>\tau_{C} can be an arbitrary value between 00 and min⁡{η,14​L​τt}𝜂14𝐿subscript𝜏𝑡\min\{\eta,\frac{1}{4L\tau_{t}}\}. Setting the stepsize ηt≡0subscript𝜂𝑡0\eta_{t}\equiv 0 is equivalent to dropping these gradients.

Proof sketch of Theorem 8.

We give the intuitive proof sketch for the case when we drop gradients with τt>τCsubscript𝜏𝑡subscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{t}>\tau_{C} and we deal with the general case in the Appendix. We know that τa​v​g≈τ¯C≤τCsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔subscript¯𝜏𝐶subscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{avg}\approx\bar{\tau}_{C}\leq\tau_{C} from Remark 5. It also holds that the number of gradients that have delay larger than the average delay τa​v​gsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔\tau_{avg} is smaller than half of all the gradients (≤T2absent𝑇2\leq\frac{T}{2}) because delays are bounded below by zero (τt≥0​∀tsubscript𝜏𝑡0for-all𝑡\tau_{t}\geq 0~{}\forall t). Thus, dropping the gradients with the delay τt>τCsubscript𝜏𝑡subscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{t}>\tau_{C}, or equivalently setting their stepsize ηt≡0subscript𝜂𝑡0\eta_{t}\equiv 0, will degrade the convergence rate at most by half, while the maximum delay among the applied ones now is equal to τCsubscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{C}. Thus we can apply result from [47] with τm​a​x=τCsubscript𝜏𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{max}=\tau_{C}. ∎

Corollary 9.

If in Algorithm 1 the concurrency is constant at every step (thus τC=τ¯Csubscript𝜏𝐶subscript¯𝜏𝐶\tau_{C}=\bar{\tau}_{C}), then under the same conditions as in Theorem 8 the convergence rate of Algorithm 1 is equal to

𝒪​(σ2ε2+τa​v​gε).𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔𝜀\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\!\left(\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{{\tau_{avg}}}{\varepsilon}\right). (13)

4.4 Discussion

Comparison to synchronous optimization.

Mini-batch SGD with batch size n𝑛n has the same degree of parallelism as Algorithm 1 with constant concurrency n𝑛n, i.e. it has n𝑛n workers computing gradients in parallel. Mini-batch SGD needs 𝒪​(σ2n​ε2+1ε)𝒪superscript𝜎2𝑛superscript𝜀21𝜀\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\big{)} [20] batches of gradients to reach an ε𝜀\varepsilon-stationary point, and thus needs 𝒪​(σ2ε2+nε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2𝑛𝜀\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{n}{\varepsilon}\big{)} gradients, as the batch-size is equal to n𝑛n. On the contrary, asynchronous SGD Algorithm 1 with stepsizes chosen as in (11) achieves exactly the same rate (13) since τa​v​g=τC=nsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔subscript𝜏𝐶𝑛\tau_{avg}=\tau_{C}=n, while its expected per-iteration time is faster than that of mini-batch SGD, as no workers have to wait for others. Thus, our result shows that asynchronous SGD is always faster than mini-batch SGD regardless of the delay pattern. A small note that in our reasoning we implicitly assumed that the sever can perform its operations in negligible time.

Tuning the stepsize.

It is worth noting that our stepsize rule (11) does not introduce any additional hyperparameters to tune compared to the constant stepsize case or to synchronous SGD. τCsubscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{C} is usually known and can be easily controlled by the server, especially in the practical constant concurrency case. Thus, to implement such a stepsize rule (11) one needs to tune only stepsize η𝜂\eta, and in case of τt>τCsubscript𝜏𝑡subscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{t}>\tau_{C} set stepsize ηt≤ητtsubscript𝜂𝑡𝜂subscript𝜏𝑡\eta_{t}\leq\frac{\eta}{\tau_{t}}.

Average v.s. maximum delay.

In a homogeneous environment when every worker computes gradients with same speed during the whole training, the average and maximum delays would be almost equal. However, occasional straggler devices will usually be present. In this case the maximum delay is much larger than the average delay.

Consider a simple example with n=2𝑛2n=2 workers, where the first worker computes gradients very fast, while the second worker returns its gradient only at the end of the training at the last iteration T𝑇T. In this case the average delay τa​v​g=2subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔2\tau_{avg}=2 is a small constant, while the maximum delay τmax=Tsubscript𝜏𝑇\tau_{\max}=T. In this case the rate depending only on the maximum delay τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max} would guarantee convergence only up to a constant accuracy ε=𝒪​(1)𝜀𝒪1\varepsilon=\mathcal{O}(1). While both rates with τmax​τa​v​gsubscript𝜏subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔\sqrt{\tau_{\max}\tau_{avg}} and with τa​v​gsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔\tau_{avg} guarantee convergence up to an arbitrary small accuracy.

Comparison to other methods.

Cohen et al. [14] recently proposed the PickySGD algorithm that achieves a convergence rate of 𝒪​(σ2ε2+τa​v​gε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔𝜀\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{{\tau_{avg}}}{\varepsilon}\big{)} (same as (13)). Their algorithm discards gradients based on the distance between the current point and the delayed one ∥𝐱(t)−𝐱(t−τt)∥delimited-∥∥superscript𝐱𝑡superscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝜏𝑡\left\lVert\mathbf{x}^{(t)}-\mathbf{x}^{(t-\tau_{t})}\right\rVert. The disadvantage of their method is that it requires sending points 𝐱(t−τt)superscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝜏𝑡\mathbf{x}^{(t-\tau_{t})} along with the gradients thus incurring twice more communications at every step. Their method also requires tuning an extra hyperparameter. In this work we achieve the same convergence rate with a much simpler method that does not require any additional communications nor additional tuning compared to synchronous SGD.

[8] also recently proposed the delay-adaptive algorithm with convergence rate depending on the average delay τa​v​gsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔\tau_{avg} for the convex and strongly convex cases. Although, our convergence rates are for the non-convex case and are not directly comparable to theirs, we highlight some key differences in their analysis. First, their convergence rate depends not only on τa​v​gsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔\tau_{avg} but also on the variance στsubscript𝜎𝜏\sigma_{\tau} of the delays, which can degrade with the maximum delay. Second, they require the bounded gradient Assumption 4. In Theorem 6 we show that under Assumption 4 no modifications to the algorithm are needed to completely remove the dependence on the maximum delay τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max} (9).

Tightness.

As we explained in Example 2, mini-batch SGD is covered by Algorithm 1. We know that mini-batch SGD convergence is lower bounded by Θ​(σ2n​ε2+1ε)Θsuperscript𝜎2𝑛superscript𝜀21𝜀\Theta\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\big{)} [4] in terms of batches processed and thus by Θ​(σ2ε2+nε)Θsuperscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2𝑛𝜀\Theta\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{n}{\varepsilon}\big{)} in terms of the gradients computed. Our convergence rate given in Theorem 6 coincides with this lower bound as in this case concurrency τC=nsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑛\tau_{C}=n, τa​v​g=τ¯C=n2subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔subscript¯𝜏𝐶𝑛2\tau_{avg}=\bar{\tau}_{C}=\frac{n}{2}.

5 Heterogeneous Distributed Setting

In this section we consider more general problems of the form (1) where the functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} are different on different nodes. This setting is motivated for example by federated learning [33, 23], where every node (client) possesses its own private data, possibly coming from a different data distribution, and thus has its own different local loss function fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}.

The setting here is therefore more general than the one considered in previous Section 4, and we will see that some of the results (with the constant stepsizes) in the homogeneous case follow as a special case of the more general results we present in this section.

5.1 Algorithm

We consider asynchronous SGD as given in Algorithm 2. Close variants of this algorithm were studied in several prior works [36, 46]. In order to simplify the presentation, we consider that concurrency is constant over time (and thus τC=τ¯Csubscript𝜏𝐶subscript¯𝜏𝐶\tau_{C}=\bar{\tau}_{C} in Definition 1). In order to allow for client subsampling often implemented in practical FL applications, we allow the concurrency τCsubscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{C} to be smaller than overall number of workers n𝑛n. The same concurrency model was recently considered in the practical FedBuff algorithm [36].

The algorithm is very similar to the homogeneous Algorithm 1 with two key differences: at line 6, the server selects clients out of all clients, and does so uniformly at random, regardless of the current active worker set 𝒞tsubscript𝒞𝑡\mathcal{C}_{t}. This means that the same client can get sampled several times, even if it didn’t finish its previous job(s) yet (thus 𝒞tsubscript𝒞𝑡\mathcal{C}_{t} is a multiset). In this case, the assigned jobs would just pile up on this client.

5.2 Theoretical analysis

We first note that our key observation on the delays (Remark 5) holds for Algorithm 2 as well. Moreover, as we have a constant concurrency τCsubscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{C} at every step, τa​v​g=𝒪​(τC)subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔𝒪subscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{avg}=\mathcal{O}\!\left(\tau_{C}\right).

Definition 10.

Denote a (possibly empty) set {τkCT,i}ksubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑘subscript𝐶𝑇𝑖𝑘\{\tau_{k}^{C_{T},i}\}_{k} to be the set of delays from gradients of the client i𝑖i that are left unapplied at the last iteration of the Algorithm 2.

We define the average delay of a client i𝑖i as

τa​v​gi=1Ti​(∑t:jt=iτt+∑kτkCT,i)superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑖1subscript𝑇𝑖subscript:𝑡subscript𝑗𝑡𝑖subscript𝜏𝑡subscript𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑘subscript𝐶𝑇𝑖\displaystyle\tau_{avg}^{i}=\frac{1}{T_{i}}\left(\sum_{t~{}:~{}j_{t}=i}\tau_{t}+\sum_{k}\tau_{k}^{C_{T},i}\right)

where Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} is the number of times the client i𝑖i got sampled during lines 1 and 6 of Algorithm 2.

Assumption 5.

The average delay τa​v​gisuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑖\tau_{avg}^{i} is independent from the number of times Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} the client i𝑖i got sampled.

Theorem 11 (constant stepsizes).

Under Assumptions 1, 2, 3, 5 there is exist a constant stepsize ηt≡ηsubscript𝜂𝑡𝜂\eta_{t}\equiv\eta such that for Algorithm 2 it holds that 1T+1​∑t=0T∥∇f​(𝐱(t))∥22≤ε1𝑇1superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝐱𝑡22𝜀\frac{1}{T+1}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(t)})\right\rVert_{2}^{2}\leq\varepsilon after

𝒪​(σ2ε2+ζ2ε2+τa​v​g​1n​∑i=1nζi2​τa​v​giε32+τa​v​g​τmaxε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2superscript𝜁2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑖2subscriptsuperscript𝜏𝑖𝑎𝑣𝑔superscript𝜀32subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔subscript𝜏𝜀\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\!\left(\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\zeta^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\sqrt{\tau_{avg}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\zeta_{i}^{2}\tau^{i}_{avg}}}{\varepsilon^{\frac{3}{2}}}+\frac{\sqrt{\tau_{avg}\tau_{\max}}}{\varepsilon}\right) iterations, (14)

Under Assumptions  1, 2, 3 and additional bounded gradient Assumption 4, it holds that 1T+1​∑t=0T∥∇f​(𝐱(t))∥22≤ε1𝑇1superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝐱𝑡22𝜀\frac{1}{T+1}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(t)})\right\rVert_{2}^{2}\leq\varepsilon after

𝒪​(σ2ε2+ζ2ε2+τa​v​g​Gε32+τa​v​gε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2superscript𝜁2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔𝐺superscript𝜀32subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔𝜀\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\!\left(\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\zeta^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\tau_{avg}G}{\varepsilon^{\frac{3}{2}}}+\frac{\tau_{avg}}{\varepsilon}\right) iterations. (15)

We note that the leading 1ε21superscript𝜀2\frac{1}{\varepsilon^{2}} term is affected by heterogeneity ζ2superscript𝜁2\zeta^{2} because at every step we apply gradient from only one client. This term is usually present in the federated learning algorithms with client subsampling see e.g. [24].

5.3 Discussion

Comparison to other works.

The recent FedBuff algorithm [36] is similar to our Algorithm 2. Their algorithm allows clients to perform several local steps and the server to wait for more than 1 client to finish compute (aka buffering), which we did not include for simplicity as these aspects are orthogonal to the effect of delays.

Disregarding these two orthogonal changes, the FedBuff algorithm is almost equivalent to our Algorithm 2 with a key difference: they assume that the client jtsubscript𝑗𝑡j_{t} that finishes computation at every step comes from the uniform distribution over all the clients. This is unrealistic to assume in practice because the server cannot control which clients finish computations at every step. In Algorithm 2 we have the more realistic assumption only on the sampling process of the clients (on line 6) that can be controlled by the server. This reflects practical client sampling in federated learning.

The convergence rate of FedBuff [36] under the bounded gradient assumption is 𝒪​(σ2ε2+ζ2ε2+(ζ2+1)​τmax​G2ε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2superscript𝜁2superscript𝜀2superscript𝜁21subscript𝜏superscript𝐺2𝜀\mathcal{O}\!\left(\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\zeta^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{(\zeta^{2}+1)\tau_{\max}G^{2}}{\varepsilon}\right). In contrast, in Theorem 11 we completely remove the dependence on the maximum delay τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max} under bounded gradients (as in Equation (15)).

Delays.

We note that for Theorem 11 we did not impose any assumption on the delays. Thus, our result allows clients and the delays on these clients to be dependent, meaning that some of the clients could be systematically slower than others. Interestingly, the middle heterogeneity term (the term with ζisubscript𝜁𝑖\zeta_{i}) is not affected by the maximum delay at all, but is affected by the average delay within each individual client. If all the heterogeneity parameters are equal, i.e. ζi=ζj,∀i,jsubscript𝜁𝑖subscript𝜁𝑗for-all𝑖𝑗\zeta_{i}=\zeta_{j},\forall i,j, then the middle term will be affected only by the overall average delay τa​v​gsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔\tau_{avg}.

Gradient clipping.

Practical implementations of FL algorithms usually apply clipping to the gradients in order to guarantee differential privacy [23]. This automatically bounds the norm of all applied gradients, making the the constant G2superscript𝐺2G^{2} in Assumption 4 small. Although we do not provide formal convergence guarantees of asynchronous SGD with gradient clipping, we envision that its convergence rate would depend only on the average delay, similar to the bounded gradient case (9), thus making the algorithm robust to stragglers.

Delay-adaptive stepsizes.

For homogeneous functions we have shown that delay-adaptive stepsizes result in a convergence rate dependent only on the average delay τa​v​gsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔\tau_{avg} without assuming bounded gradients (as in Equation (11)). However in the heterogeneous case this is not so straightforward. Delay-adaptive learning rate schemes will introduce a bias towards the clients that compute quickly, and Algorithm 2 would converge to the wrong objective.

It is interesting to note that current popular schemes implemented in practice for FL over-selects the clients at every iteration [11]. The server waits only for some percentage (e.g. 80%) of sampled clients and discards the rest. Such a scheme also introduces a bias towards fast workers. A delay-adaptive learning rate scheme is expected to introduce less bias as the gradients are still applied but with the smaller weight. We leave this question for future practical investigations, as it is not the focus of our current work.

Independent delays.

If the delays and the clients are independent (e.g. coming from the same distribution for all of the clients), then the convergence rate of Algorithm 2 will simplify to 𝒪​(σ2ε2+ζ​τa​v​gε32+τa​v​g​τmaxε)𝒪superscript𝜎2superscript𝜀2𝜁subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔superscript𝜀32subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔subscript𝜏𝜀\mathcal{O}\!\left(\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\zeta\tau_{avg}}{\varepsilon^{\frac{3}{2}}}+\frac{\sqrt{\tau_{avg}\tau_{\max}}}{\varepsilon}\right) (without needing bounded gradient assumption). In this case it is also possible to use delay-adaptive stepsizes (similar to Theorem 8) to completely remove the dependence on the maximum delays τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max} without assuming bounded gradients.

Extensions.

We can extend the Algorithm 2 and our theoretical analysis to allow clients to perform several local steps, before sending back the change in 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}. We can also extend Algorithm 2 to allow the server to wait for the first K𝐾K clients to finish computations rather than just one, similar to [36]. These extensions are straightforward and we excluded them here for simplicity of presentation.

Finally, we can also extend Algorithm 2 to sample new clients as soon as some previous client finished compute, without waiting for the server update on the line 5.

5.4 Estimating Speedup over Synchronous SGD

Assume we have n𝑛n clients, each of which having a different but constant time to compute a gradient {Δi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptΔ𝑖𝑖1𝑛\{\Delta_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}. W.l.o.g. we assume that ΔisubscriptΔ𝑖\Delta_{i} are ordered as Δ1≤Δ2≤⋯≤ΔnsubscriptΔ1subscriptΔ2⋯subscriptΔ𝑛\Delta_{1}\leq\Delta_{2}\leq\dots\leq\Delta_{n}.

Lemma 12.

In expectation, the asynchronous Algorithm 2 needs

Δ¯=1n​∑i=1nΔi¯Δ1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscriptΔ𝑖\displaystyle\bar{\Delta}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\Delta_{i}

time to compute τCsubscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{C} gradients, while mini-batch SGD with batch size τCsubscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{C} needs

Δ~=∑i=1nαi​Δi~Δsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝛼𝑖subscriptΔ𝑖\displaystyle\tilde{\Delta}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\alpha_{i}\Delta_{i}

time to compute a batch of τCsubscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{C} gradients, where αi=iτC−(i−1)τCnτCsubscript𝛼𝑖superscript𝑖subscript𝜏𝐶superscript𝑖1subscript𝜏𝐶superscript𝑛subscript𝜏𝐶\alpha_{i}=\frac{i^{\tau_{C}}-(i-1)^{\tau_{C}}}{n^{\tau_{C}}}. It is also always holds that Δ¯≤Δ~¯Δ~Δ\bar{\Delta}\leq\tilde{\Delta}.

With this lemma we can precisely estimate how much faster the asynchronous algorithm is compared to the classic synchronous mini-batch one. Note that αisubscript𝛼𝑖\alpha_{i} are increasing with i𝑖i with a rate of 𝒪​(iτC)𝒪superscript𝑖subscript𝜏𝐶\mathcal{O}(i^{\tau_{C}}), thus in mini-batch SGD, the large delays get a much higher weight than the small delays, especially when the batch size τCsubscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{C} is large.

For example, consider 100010001000 clients, 900900900 of which compute their update every 101010s, while 100100100 of them computes their update every 60​s60𝑠60s. Then the expected time for τCsubscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{C} gradients of the asynchronous algorithm will be 151515s, while synchronous mini-batch SGD (with τC=10subscript𝜏𝐶10\tau_{C}=10) will take a significantly longer time of 42.542.542.5s for the same number of gradients.

6 Conclusion

In this paper we study the asynchronous SGD algorithm both in homogeneous and heterogeneous settings. By leveraging the notion of concurrency—the number of workers that compute gradients in parallel—we show a much faster convergence rate for asynchronous SGD, improving the dependence on the maximum delay τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max} over prior works, for both homogeneous and heterogeneous objectives. Our proof technique also allows to design a simple delay-adaptive stepsize rule (11) that attains a convergence rate depending only on the average delay τa​v​gsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔\tau_{avg} that neither requires any additional tuning, nor additional communication. Our techniques allows us to demonstrate that asynchronous SGD is faster than mini-batch SGD for any delay pattern.

Appendix A Proofs

In this section we provide the proofs of all the theoretical results stated in the main paper.

A.1 Proof of Remark 5

First, we prove our key observation given in Remark 5. See 5

Proof.

Indeed, one of the gradients from 𝒞tsubscript𝒞𝑡\mathcal{C}_{t} got applied and its delay moved from τs​u​mactive,tsubscriptsuperscript𝜏active𝑡𝑠𝑢𝑚\tau^{\text{active},t}_{sum} to τs​u​mapplied,t+1superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑠𝑢𝑚applied𝑡1\tau_{sum}^{\text{applied},t+1}. The newly selected active workers in line 6 of Algorithm 1 have delay zero, as they just started their computations in this step. And all of the current active workers in 𝒞t+1subscript𝒞𝑡1\mathcal{C}_{t+1} (of size |𝒞t+1|=τC(t+1)subscript𝒞𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑡1|\mathcal{C}_{t+1}|=\tau_{C}^{(t+1)}) got an increase by 1 due to increase of the iteration count from t𝑡t to t+1𝑡1t+1.

Using the initial conditions (16) and (17) we can conclude that

τs​u​mapplied,T+τs​u​mactive,T=∑t=0TτC(t)=(T+1)​τ¯C.superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑠𝑢𝑚applied𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝜏active𝑇𝑠𝑢𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑡𝑇1subscript¯𝜏𝐶\displaystyle\tau_{sum}^{\text{applied},T}+\tau^{\text{active},T}_{sum}=\sum_{t=0}^{T}\tau_{C}^{(t)}=(T+1)\bar{\tau}_{C}\,.

Note that the left hand side is exactly equal to (T+|CT|−1)​τa​v​g𝑇subscript𝐶𝑇1subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔(T+|C_{T}|-1)\tau_{avg} from our Definition 4. Thus,

τa​v​g=T+1T+|CT|−1​τ¯C=𝒪​(τ¯C),subscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑇1𝑇subscript𝐶𝑇1subscript¯𝜏𝐶𝒪subscript¯𝜏𝐶\displaystyle\tau_{avg}=\frac{T+1}{T+|C_{T}|-1}\bar{\tau}_{C}=\mathcal{O}\left(\bar{\tau}_{C}\right)\,,

where the last equality holds if T>|CT|𝑇subscript𝐶𝑇T>|C_{T}|. ∎

A.3.1 Proof of Theorem 6, convergence rate (8)

Lemma 15 (Estimation of the residual).

Under Assumptions 1 and 3, the iterates of Algorithm 1 with the constant stepsize ηt≡ηsubscript𝜂𝑡𝜂\eta_{t}\equiv\eta with η≤12​L​τmax​τC𝜂12𝐿subscript𝜏subscript𝜏𝐶\eta\leq\frac{1}{2L\sqrt{\tau_{\max}\tau_{C}}} satisfy

1T+1∑t=0T𝔼∥𝐱(t)−𝐱(t−τt)∥22≤14​L2​(T+1)∑t=0T𝔼∥∇f(𝐱(t−τt))∥2+σ2​η2​L.\displaystyle\frac{1}{T+1}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert{\mathbf{x}}^{(t)}-\mathbf{x}^{(t-\tau_{t})}\right\rVert_{2}^{2}\leq\frac{1}{4L^{2}(T+1)}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(t-\tau_{t})})\right\rVert^{2}+\frac{\sigma^{2}\eta}{2L}\,.
Proof.

We start with unrolling the difference and use that 𝔼​∇F​(𝐱(j−τj),ξ(j−τj))=∇f​(𝐱(j−τj))𝔼∇𝐹superscript𝐱𝑗subscript𝜏𝑗superscript𝜉𝑗subscript𝜏𝑗∇𝑓superscript𝐱𝑗subscript𝜏𝑗\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\nabla F(\mathbf{x}^{(j-\tau_{j})},\xi^{(j-\tau_{j})})=\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(j-\tau_{j})}).

𝔼∥𝐱(t)−𝐱(t−τt)∥22\displaystyle\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert{\mathbf{x}}^{(t)}-\mathbf{x}^{(t-\tau_{t})}\right\rVert_{2}^{2} =𝔼∥∑j=t−τtt−1η∇F(𝐱(j−τj),ξj)∥2≤(​5​)𝔼∥∑j=t−τtt−1η∇f(𝐱(j−τj))∥2+τtη2σ2\displaystyle=\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert\sum_{j=t-\tau_{t}}^{t-1}\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{x}^{(j-\tau_{j})},\xi_{j})\right\rVert^{2}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\eqref{eq:bounded_gradient}}}{{\leq}}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert\sum_{j=t-\tau_{t}}^{t-1}\eta\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(j-\tau_{j})})\right\rVert^{2}+\tau_{t}\eta^{2}\sigma^{2}
≤(​18​)τt​𝔼​∑j=t−τtt−1η2​∥∇f​(𝐱(j−τj))∥2+τt​η2​σ2.superscriptitalic-(18italic-)absentsubscript𝜏𝑡𝔼superscriptsubscript𝑗𝑡subscript𝜏𝑡𝑡1superscript𝜂2superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝐱𝑗subscript𝜏𝑗2subscript𝜏𝑡superscript𝜂2superscript𝜎2\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\eqref{eq:norm_of_sum}}}{{\leq}}\tau_{t}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\sum_{j=t-\tau_{t}}^{t-1}\eta^{2}\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(j-\tau_{j})})\right\rVert^{2}+\tau_{t}\eta^{2}\sigma^{2}\,.

Using that η≤12​L​τmax​τC𝜂12𝐿subscript𝜏subscript𝜏𝐶\eta\leq\frac{1}{2L\sqrt{\tau_{\max}\tau_{C}}},

𝔼∥𝐱(t)−𝐱(t−τt)∥22≤14​L2​τC∑j=t−τtt−1𝔼∥∇f(𝐱(j−τj))∥2+τtη2σ2.\displaystyle\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert{\mathbf{x}}^{(t)}-\mathbf{x}^{(t-\tau_{t})}\right\rVert_{2}^{2}\leq\frac{1}{4L^{2}\tau_{C}}\sum_{j=t-\tau_{t}}^{t-1}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(j-\tau_{j})})\right\rVert^{2}+\tau_{t}\eta^{2}\sigma^{2}\,.

Summing over T𝑇T,

∑t=0T𝔼∥𝐱(t)−𝐱(t−τt)∥22\displaystyle\sum_{t=0}^{T}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert{\mathbf{x}}^{(t)}-\mathbf{x}^{(t-\tau_{t})}\right\rVert_{2}^{2} ≤14​L2​τC∑t=0T∑j=t−τtt−1𝔼∥∇f(𝐱(j−τj))∥2+∑t=0Tτtη2σ2\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{4L^{2}\tau_{C}}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\sum_{j=t-\tau_{t}}^{t-1}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(j-\tau_{j})})\right\rVert^{2}+\sum_{t=0}^{T}\tau_{t}\eta^{2}\sigma^{2}

We now observe that the number of times each of the gradients ∥∇f​(𝐱(j−τj))∥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝐱𝑗subscript𝜏𝑗2\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(j-\tau_{j})})\right\rVert^{2} appears in the right hand side is bounded by τC(j)−1superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑗1\tau_{C}^{(j)}-1 because this many gradients started to be computed before the iteration j𝑗j and will get applied at some iteration t>j𝑡𝑗t>j. Thus,

∑t=0T𝔼∥𝐱(t)−𝐱(t−τt)∥22≤14​L2∑t=0T𝔼∥∇f(𝐱(t−τt))∥2+(T+1)σ2​η2​L,\displaystyle\sum_{t=0}^{T}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert{\mathbf{x}}^{(t)}-\mathbf{x}^{(t-\tau_{t})}\right\rVert_{2}^{2}\leq\frac{1}{4L^{2}}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(t-\tau_{t})})\right\rVert^{2}+(T+1)\frac{\sigma^{2}\eta}{2L}\,,

where for the last σ𝜎\sigma term we estimated η≤12​L​τmax​τC𝜂12𝐿subscript𝜏subscript𝜏𝐶\eta\leq\frac{1}{2L\sqrt{\tau_{\max}\tau_{C}}} and used that both τa​v​g≤τCsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔subscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{avg}\leq\tau_{C} and τa​v​g≤τmaxsubscript𝜏𝑎𝑣𝑔subscript𝜏\tau_{avg}\leq\tau_{\max}. Dividing the inequality by T+1𝑇1T+1 we get the statement of the lemma. ∎

Next, we give the proof of the first part of Theorem 6.

A.4 Proof of Theorem 6, convergence rate (9)

To prove the last claim of Theorem 6 we take another approach and follow the perturbed iterate analysis [30].

Lemma 18 (Estimation of the residual).

Under Assumptions 1, 3, iterated of Algorithm 1 with the constant stepsize ηt≡ηsubscript𝜂𝑡𝜂\eta_{t}\equiv\eta with η≤12​L​τC𝜂12𝐿subscript𝜏𝐶\eta\leq\frac{1}{2L\tau_{C}} satisfy

Proof.

≤(​18​)τC(t)∑j∈𝒞tη2𝔼∥∇f(𝐱(j))∥22+η2τC(t)σ2\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\eqref{eq:norm_of_sum}}}{{\leq}}\tau_{C}^{(t)}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{C}_{t}}\eta^{2}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(j)})\right\rVert_{2}^{2}+\eta^{2}\tau_{C}^{(t)}\sigma^{2}
≤(​5​)(τC(t))2​η2​G2+η2​τC(t)​σ2.superscriptitalic-(5italic-)absentsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑡2superscript𝜂2superscript𝐺2superscript𝜂2superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑡superscript𝜎2\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\eqref{eq:bounded_gradient}}}{{\leq}}(\tau_{C}^{(t)})^{2}\eta^{2}G^{2}+\eta^{2}\tau_{C}^{(t)}\sigma^{2}\,.

∎

We are now ready to prove the second claim of Theorem 6.

A.5.1 Proof of Theorem 11, convergence rate (14)

Lemma 20 (Estimation of the distance ∥𝐱(t)−𝐱~(t)∥22superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝐱𝑡superscript~𝐱𝑡22\left\lVert{\mathbf{x}}^{(t)}-\tilde{\mathbf{x}}^{(t)}\right\rVert_{2}^{2}).

Proof.

We note that in the second term each of ζjsubscript𝜁𝑗\zeta_{j} appears exactly τjs​u​msuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑗𝑠𝑢𝑚\tau_{j}^{sum} times, where τjs​u​msuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑗𝑠𝑢𝑚\tau_{j}^{sum} is the sum of the all the delays that happened on the node j𝑗j. we further use that number of times Tjsubscript𝑇𝑗T_{j} that every node j𝑗j got sampled are equal in expectation because of uniform sampling in line 6 of Algorithm 2. Thus,

Proof of Theorem 11, (14).

First, averaging the descent Lemma 17,

1T+1∑t=0T𝔼∥∇f(𝐱(t))∥22≤4η​(T+1)(f(𝐱0)−f(𝐱T))+2Lησ2+4Lηζ2+2​L2T+1∑t=0T𝔼∥𝐱(t)−𝐱~(t)∥22.\displaystyle\frac{1}{T+1}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert\nabla f({\mathbf{x}}^{(t)})\right\rVert_{2}^{2}\leq\frac{4}{\eta(T+1)}\left(f(\mathbf{x}^{0})-f(\mathbf{x}^{{T}})\right)+2L\eta\sigma^{2}+4L\eta\zeta^{2}+\frac{2L^{2}}{T+1}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left\lVert{\mathbf{x}}^{(t)}-\tilde{\mathbf{x}}^{(t)}\right\rVert_{2}^{2}\,.

It is only left to tune the stepsize using Lemma 17 in [25]. ∎

Proof of the Theorem 11, (15).

We start by averaging the descent Lemma 17,

It is only left to tune the stepsize using Lemma 17 in [25]. ∎

A.6 Proof of Lemma 12

In this section we prove Lemma 12 that estimates expected execution time of Algorithm 2 with concurrency τC=Csubscript𝜏𝐶𝐶\tau_{C}=C, and the expected time of mini-batch SGD with the same concurrency i.e. batch size equal to τC=Csubscript𝜏𝐶𝐶\tau_{C}=C.

Proof.

We start by proving the first claim.

Time of Asynchronous Algorithm 2.

Assume the concurrency is C=1𝐶1C=1. Then, Algorithm 2 is synchronous, and as we sample every client with equal probability (line 6 of Algorithm 2), the expected time to compute one gradient is equal to 1n​∑i=1nΔi1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscriptΔ𝑖\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\Delta_{i}.

To calculate the estimated time with concurrency C>1𝐶1C>1 we can view the Algorithm 2 as having C𝐶C independent copies of the previous process run in parallel. Thus, in the same time 1n​∑i=1nΔi1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscriptΔ𝑖\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\Delta_{i} in expectation Algorithm 2 will compute C𝐶C gradients.

Time of Mini-batch SGD.

The expected time of mini-batch SGD of size C𝐶C is equal to 𝔼⁡max⁡{Δi1,…,ΔiC}𝔼subscriptΔsubscript𝑖1…subscriptΔsubscript𝑖𝐶\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\max\{\Delta_{i_{1}},\dots,\Delta_{i_{C}}\} with each ij∼Uniform⁡[1,n]similar-tosubscript𝑖𝑗Uniform1𝑛i_{j}\sim\operatorname{Uniform}[1,n]. Denote a random variable X=max⁡{Δi1,…,ΔiC}𝑋subscriptΔsubscript𝑖1…subscriptΔsubscript𝑖𝐶X=\max\{\Delta_{i_{1}},\dots,\Delta_{i_{C}}\} that takes values within Δ1,…​ΔnsubscriptΔ1…subscriptΔ𝑛\Delta_{1},\dots\Delta_{n}. Since ijsubscript𝑖𝑗i_{j} are independent from each other,

Pr​[X≤Δk]=∏j=1CPr​[Δij≤Δk]=∏j=1CPr​[X≤Δk]=∏j=1CPr​[ij≤k]=(kn)C.Prdelimited-[]𝑋subscriptΔ𝑘superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗1𝐶Prdelimited-[]subscriptΔsubscript𝑖𝑗subscriptΔ𝑘superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗1𝐶Prdelimited-[]𝑋subscriptΔ𝑘superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗1𝐶Prdelimited-[]subscript𝑖𝑗𝑘superscript𝑘𝑛𝐶\displaystyle{\rm Pr}\left[X\leq\Delta_{k}\right]=\prod_{j=1}^{C}{\rm Pr}\left[\Delta_{i_{j}}\leq\Delta_{k}\right]=\prod_{j=1}^{C}{\rm Pr}\left[X\leq\Delta_{k}\right]=\prod_{j=1}^{C}{\rm Pr}\left[{i_{j}}\leq k\right]=\left(\frac{k}{n}\right)^{C}\,.

Thus,

Pr​[X=Δk]=kC−(k−1)CnC.Prdelimited-[]𝑋subscriptΔ𝑘superscript𝑘𝐶superscript𝑘1𝐶superscript𝑛𝐶\displaystyle{\rm Pr}\left[X=\Delta_{k}\right]=\frac{k^{C}-(k-1)^{C}}{n^{C}}\,.

And therefore,

𝔼⁡X𝔼𝑋\displaystyle\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}X =∑k=1nPr​[X=Δk]​Δk.∎absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛Prdelimited-[]𝑋subscriptΔ𝑘subscriptΔ𝑘\displaystyle=\sum_{k=1}^{n}{\rm Pr}\left[X=\Delta_{k}\right]\Delta_{k}\,.\qed

Appendix B Experiments

In this set of experiments we aim to illustrate the dependence on the maximum delay τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max} in Theorem 6, as depicted in Equation (8). For this, we set the stochastic noise σ𝜎\sigma to zero. In this case Theorem 6, Equation (8) predicts that to reach an ε𝜀\varepsilon accuracy, Algorithm 1 needs T=𝒪​(τmax​τCε)𝑇𝒪subscript𝜏subscript𝜏𝐶𝜀T=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\sqrt{\tau_{\max}\tau_{C}}}{\varepsilon}\right) iterations. In our experiments we fix τC=2subscript𝜏𝐶2\tau_{C}=2, ε=10−14𝜀superscript1014\varepsilon=10^{-14}. Since τC=2subscript𝜏𝐶2\tau_{C}=2, we have two workers. We vary the relative speed of the second worker, and thus affecting the maximum delay: if the second worker is x𝑥x times slower than the first worker, then the maximum delay τmax=xsubscript𝜏𝑥\tau_{\max}=x. We measure the time T𝑇T to reach the accuracy ε𝜀\varepsilon. Since all the other parameters are constant, it holds that T=C1​τmax𝑇subscript𝐶1subscript𝜏T=C_{1}\sqrt{\tau_{\max}}.

We perform experiments on two different functions:

  • (i)

    quadratic function f​(𝐱)=12​∥A​𝐱−𝐛∥22𝑓𝐱12superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐴𝐱𝐛22f(\mathbf{x})=\frac{1}{2}\left\lVert A\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{b}\right\rVert_{2}^{2}, 𝐱,𝐛∈ℝ10𝐱𝐛superscriptℝ10\mathbf{x},\mathbf{b}\in\mathbb{R}^{10}, bi∼𝒩​(0,1),i∈[1,10]formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscript𝑏𝑖𝒩01𝑖110b_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1),i\in[1,10], A∈ℝ10×10𝐴superscriptℝ1010A\in\mathbb{R}^{10\times 10} is a random matrix with λmax​(A)=2subscript𝜆𝐴2\lambda_{\max}(A)=2, λmin​(A)=1subscript𝜆𝐴1\lambda_{\min}(A)=1 and the rest of eigenvalues are equally spaced in between.

  • (ii)

    logistic regression function f​(𝐱)=1m​∑j=1mlog⁡(1+exp⁡(−bj​𝐚j⊤​𝐱))𝑓𝐱1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚1subscript𝑏𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐚𝑗top𝐱f(\mathbf{x})=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}\log(1+\exp(-b_{j}\mathbf{a}_{j}^{\top}\mathbf{x})), where each bjsubscript𝑏𝑗b_{j} is sampled uniformly at random from the set {−1,1}11\{-1,1\}, and 𝐚j∼𝒩​(0,1)20similar-tosubscript𝐚𝑗𝒩superscript0120\mathbf{a}_{j}\sim\mathcal{N}\left(0,1\right)^{20}, 𝐱∈ℝ20𝐱superscriptℝ20\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{20}, m=100𝑚100m=100.

We estimate the error as the average over the last 30 iterations ε^T=130​∑i=029∥∇f​(𝐱T−i)∥2subscript^𝜀𝑇130superscriptsubscript𝑖029subscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑇𝑖2\hat{\varepsilon}_{T}=\frac{1}{30}\sum_{i=0}^{29}\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{T-i})\right\rVert_{2}. We tune the stepsize η𝜂\eta for every experiment separately over the logarithmic grid between 10−5superscript10510^{-5} and 102superscript10210^{2} ensuring that the optimal stepsize value is not on the edge of the grid.

Figure 2 shows the resulting dependence of T𝑇T on τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max} for the quadratic function (i), and Figure 2 for the logistic regression function (ii). In both cases we see that T𝑇T has linear dependence on τmaxsubscript𝜏\sqrt{\tau_{\max}} confirming our theory.
